@behaviourresol1 Completely agree. The most powerful 'intervention' there is, a trusted adult who is kind, curious & listening.
Chris is a poet & printer now, working with homeless people in Sheffield. He concludes, "We live in such a judgemental society. We need to start asking What happened to you?"

At school, he was just a naughty child. There was no professional curiosity. If he trusted anyone enough to tell his story, there would have been immediate intervention & his entire life course have been different.

This interview between forensic psychologists & 'human crime wave' Chris makes the most devastatingly eloquent case for trauma informed services & a trauma informed society that you will ever hear. 
https://t.co/LfpnJaM5Fy

"Removal from the classroom should be considered a serious sanction. It should only be used when necessary and once other behavioural strategies in the classroom have been attempted, unless the behaviour is so extreme as to warrant immediate removal."

Parents should be informed on the same day if their 
child has been removed from the classroom. This includes the corporate parent.

Schools should refer pupils into each other's 'pupil support units'.  Pretty sure this isn't common practice  but maybe it's a vision of the future. Transport arrangements are to be agreed through 'collaboration' with the LA.
Partners & agencies are going to be busy: a lack of resilience and difficulties with peer relationships & social skills are for them to address. (98)

Two very different processes are being yoked together here in an unhelpful way. A managed move has to be voluntary. A direction off-site doesn't...it's a direction & not how managed moves are brokered.

That would see a return of the off-site direction followed by the off-rolling in Y11 that used to be widespread.
It would also miss the whole point of a managed move, which is to give the pupil a chance to remain in mainstream.

@TeachBehaviour @SophieR66723937 @grahamchatterl2 @KimSGolding @Markfinnis @paul66mtc üíØ
Roots of Empathy fascinates me. I know @DizzyDoodler is a strong advocate & I know it has a strong evudence base, but I've never actually seen it.

There's a lot of social & emotional skill involved...so being a restorative school is for me absolutely the right thing because it means there's a commitment to building those essential skills. But on the individual student level, it doesn't mean everyone has them yet.

Skip that process with highly distressed CYP, & they can find themselves in even more bother - facing PEX even - for 'lack of remorse'. Everyone hates to see that...so avoid demanding it too soon. And spare the other party who only feels more frustration & hurt when RP flounders.

Expecting CYP who haven't known empathy to feel & express it is unrealistic. Consistent, empathic boundary setting (which Kim writes brilliantly about) builds the foundation for restorative intervention to succeed.

If you put a CYP in a restorative arena when they're in survival mode (chronically, I'm not referring to being temporarily at 5 on the stress scale) it's not going to be productive. The thermostat isn't set on social engagement & there's work required - over time - to fix that. https://t.co/b6uyiOsyal

E - Equity
Being flexible for those that need extra or different. 
What are your policies around gender, race, sexuality, mental health?

R - Respect

For individuals & for culture.

I - INCLUSION

feeling you belong one of strongest factors in wellbeing.
Exclusive belonging, though, is dangerous at societal level. 
Inclusive belonging welcomes everyone. It's open to all.

P - Positivity

Identification of strengths in self & others. Having fun together. Encouraging playfulness & laughter...releases oxytocin, the feel good hormone which makes us feel warmer towards others & more collaborative.

S - SAFETY
Comes with being accepted for who you are, not being singled out, feeling someone has your back, being able to trust others will do as they say.

I wrote a blog about this once, with my colleague's approval - why I'm happy to share it.

Not surprisingly, from that day forward, the boy's behaviour in that teacher's lesson was impeccable. He learned a lesson to carry through life.

We could have just excluded him.

Having said he would not dicuss his sexuality as a condition of taking part, my colleague obviously changed his mind towards the end. And he was absolutely brilliant on the impact that this kind of behaviour has on a person. There were tears of remorse from the family.

Most impactful restorative conference I ever chaired was between a gay teacher (not out in any deliberate way at school) & pupil who had engaged in covert homophobic bullying. My colleague  agreed to participate (under no pressure at all) with boy, his auntie & mum also attending https://t.co/gSy2YGrl7k

The law reflects the fact that direction into a setting that wasn't the family's choice is a very big deal.

Again, not always how it works with pupils often directed into AP and remaining there, albeit now generally dual registered rather than off-rolled. If they are not expected to return after the intervention that this direction off-site is supposed to represent, that's an issue.

The move into AP without a PEX is lawful under the Headteacher's power to direct off-site to improve behaviour. This can be a unilateral decision - unlike managed moves, with require parental consent. However, regular review against the desired outcomes is required.

Outcomes of the managed move cohort are difficult to capture. Good to see FFT grapple with it. However, a move into AP isn't a managed move, unless there's a trial period & a safety net back at mainstream school should the AP call time. Not how it works.

When O levels were introduced, we didn't know any of this stuff. We do now ... and as an evidence-based system we should be interested in the implications, not wedded to the past and oblivious to stats like those at the top of this thread.
It's a time of opportunity  - neural plasticity is always that - but also of huge vulnerability, which is why most mental illnesses begin during this period.

This presentation from one of the world's leading experts on adolesence, who we ought to be listening to, outlines the profound neural upheaval that occurs during this highly sensitive developmental period. Mhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y50MtKCH8O0

We also render them incapable by piling on too much pressure. Calls to childline about exam stress doubled in the same year that reformed GCSEs were introduced. Nearly 1m young people are now severely absent, with research from @minds confirming this is frequently stress related. https://t.co/sIenbgUot8

Think about whether our traditional response to dysregulated behaviour  is regulating (isolation?)....or whether it further unbalances.

In terms of catch up, think about what happens to access to the thinking brain when we feel out of balance, stressed.

"As we grow up, we find our own regulating rhythms & activities. For some of us, it's walking. For others, it's riding a bike. Everyone has their own go-to options when they feel out of sync, anxious or frustrated. The common element is rhythm. Rhythm is regulating."

I get that behaviourism is very deeply embedded in our culture, but we need to be able to discuss its limitations in a serious way. Until we can do that, we really will remain the poor relation of Europe in relation to inclusion.
My point ‚Äì returning to Lena‚Äôs lovely blog: consequences don‚Äôt teach skills and sanctioning still developing children *for lacking them* can do all manner of harm and no good.

Extremely hard work. At 15 she hit crisis ‚Äì hospital for a time. We decided then to pursue the diagnosis of autism which is now a great solace to her as she journeys towards self-acceptance and develops strategies which make life easier.

As an older child, she developed some of that ability, or how to present like she had it ‚Äì‚Äì and was never a spot of bother for staff at secondary school. It was hard work though, learning socially appropriate behaviour which was never intuitive.

Never once was she reprimanded for difficulties sustaining attention or sitting still. That didn't mean that all pupils had licence to wriggle about and not pay attention. (The school remains Ofsted Outstanding, rightly)

In YR, she got into frequent trouble for fiddling about on the carpet and not paying attention. She was soon utterly miserable about going to school. We moved her and the next setting engaged an EP ‚Äì spikiest profile of underlying ability you could imagine.

On a family holiday, (then) sister-in-law advised that she needed ‚Äútraining like a dog‚Äù (consistent consequences). No part of me thought that was a good idea, though I didn‚Äôt bother debating it. (People have strong views about consequences - see earlier thread) She was just 2 yo.

More personal experience relevant here. 
Youngest was an extremely tricky toddler. Didn‚Äôt take a blind bit of notice of her parents a lot of the time ‚Äì completely her own agenda.

@MrN_Primary Talk about why that's not ok, what the impact was on others if that's not clear, the real consequences. Seek assurance that there will never be a repeat. Just like can happen  in the real world of work when we mess up.
